title.narrative: UN-ACT Action against trafficking in Person in GMS SEA 2014-2016
UN-ACT Action against trafficking in Person in GMSAnti-trafficking SEA 2014-2016

description.narrative: The Objectives of the intervention are framed in accordance with the UN-ACT initiative which later on transited into the DMD pilot study. UN-ACT The objective: Key anti-trafficking stakeholders in the region are working in a more cooperative and mutually supportive manner to effectively combat trafficking in persons. The UN-ACT programme activities were planned around the 4 main outputs as follow: Output 1: The COMMIT Process is strengthened to become sustainable and self-reliant Output 2: COMMIT countries increase their cooperation with other countries and regional actors to effectively counter human trafficking Output 3: Policy makers, academia, non-state actors and the public have increased access to evidence-based research and knowledge on human trafficking Output 4: Civil society and other non-governmental actors are able to contribute more effectively to anti-trafficking efforts DMD Pilot Initiative According to the latest concept note, the objective of the pilot initiative is re-formulated as follows: "The resilience of migrants, displaced people and host communities in informal urban settlements to shocks and crises is strengthened,” Note: Resilience in this context is defined as an enabler for development which means 'a transformative process of strengthening the capacity of people, communities, institutions, and countries to anticipate, prevent, recover from and transform in the aftermath of shocks, stresses and change'. The objective could be achieved through the intervention of four components; 1. Mitigation of disasters, climate events and change (migration as a choice) 2. Strengthening social cohesion 3. Improving livelihoods 4. Enhancing urban planning and development including access to health and other key services (re-integration)

Insatsen syftar till att bidra till samarbete och stöd till de viktigaste intressenterna i Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) som arbetar för att bekämpa människohandel för att öka insatsernas effektivitet. Interventionen kommer att hanteras och genomföras av UNDP Asia Pacific Regional Center (UNDP APRC) och projektet UN-ACT (Action for Cooperation against Trafficking in persons) och hanteras av UNDP: s regiondirektör och en regional projektledare. UNDP har utvecklat ett projektdokument 2013 baserat på prioriteringar och utmaningar i arbetet med att bekämpa människohandel identifierat av de sex länderna i GMS-regionen, det civila samhället och andra aktörer.
Resultatet av UN-ACT är viktiga intressenter mot människohandel i regionen arbetar på ett mer samarbetsvilligt och ömsesidigt stödjande sätt för att effektivt bekämpa människohandel. Resultatet förväntas uppnås genom de fyra resultatområdena som följer. 1, COMMIT-processen stärks för att bli hållbar och självförsörjande; 2. COMMIT-länderna ökar sitt samarbete med andra länder och regionala aktörer för att effektivt motverka människohandel. 3. Politiska beslutsfattare, forsknings aktörer , icke-statliga aktörer och allmänheten har ökad tillgången till evidensbaserad forskning och kunskap om människohandel. 4. Det civila samhället och andra icke-statliga aktörer kan bidra mer effektivt till insatser mot människohandel
År 2019 började övergången till UN-ACT. Driften av COMMIT-processen överförs från programmet till COMMIT-länderna. UN-ACT-programmet har gradvis flyttat fokus från människohandel till migrations- och utvecklingssamarbete. viktiga lärdomar och resultat från UN-ACT-programmet, med betoning på jämställdhet och rättighetsperspektivet Genomförandet för migration och utveckling är planerad till 2020.

The intervention aims to contribute to the collaboration and support to the key stakeholders in the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) working to combat human trafficking in order to increase the effectiveness of the efforts. The intervention will be managed and implemented by the UNDP Asia Pacific Regional Center (UNDP APRC) and the project UN-ACT (Action for Cooperation against Trafficking in persons) is under the direct supervision of the UNDP regional director and a regional project manager. UNDP has developed a project document in 2013 based on top priorities and challenges in efforts to combat human trafficking according to the six countries of the GMS region, civil society and other actors.
The outcome of UN-ACT is Key anti-trafficking stakeholders in the region are working in a more cooperative and mutually supportive manner to effectively combat trafficking in persons. The outcome is anticipated to achieve through the 4 result areas as follow. 1, The COMMIT Process is strengthened to become sustainable and self-reliant; 2. COMMIT countries increase their cooperation with other countries and regional actors to effectively counter human trafficking; 3. Policy makers, academia, non-state actors and the public have increased access to evidence-based research and knowledge on human trafficking; 4. Civil society and other non-governmental actors are able to contribute more effectively to anti-trafficking efforts
In 2019, the transition of UN-ACT has started. The operation of the COMMIT process is transferred from the programme to the COMMIT countries. The UN-ACT programme has gradually shifted its focus from human trafficking to migration & development framework (M&D) by drawing lessons learnt and key findings from UN-ACT programme particularly gender responsive and human rights-based approach. The scoping activities for M&D framework are planned for 2020.

participating-org.narrative: United Nations Agency, Fund or Commission

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Through the phase-out of UN-ACT, the following were achieved; -Anti-trafficking stakeholders in the region are working together more effectively to combat human trafficking at sub-regional, bilateral, and national level as a result of UN-ACT’s work. Multilateral cooperation is strengthened, with the COMMIT Process continuing to provide a crucial means for determining sub-regional priorities and strategy amongst COMMIT government and non-government stakeholders. -Within most COMMIT countries, there are stronger partnerships amongst government agencies, stimulated by National COMMIT Task Forces, which are working to bring responses to trafficking in line with international standards. -Since 2014, 14,307 trafficked persons have been referred to protection and support services, and 60 positive policy changes have come as a result of multi-stakeholder advocacy. -During the phase-out of the programme, the progresses were most apparent in the area of victims protection, with GMS governments taking practical steps towards the development of National Referral Mechanisms (NRM) – notably driving the development of national framework documents through multi-stakeholder consultation – as part of UN-ACT’s catalytic initiative on Trans Natioanl Referral Mechanism- (T)NRM. -COVID-related disruption notwithstanding, the project achieved results in some countries, with new guiding NRM framework documents produced and approved or in the final stages of approval in Lao PDR and Cambodia. -Direct capacity building was also undertaken within Thailand, which already has relatively well developed referral processes through the Multi-Disciplinary Team structure. These trainings also served as a pilot for a new Regional Curriculum on Victim Identification, Protection, Assistance and (Re)Integration. -UNDP will continue to serve as secretariat to COMMIT, working specifically on the development of a TRM for the subregion through UNDP’s Inclusion for Development Programme and the EU-funded ILO-IOM-UNDP Ship to Shore Rights Programme. Many of the secretariat functions have, however, already been taken on by member governments with UNDP primarily providing technical and coordination support. By the end of 2020, the pilot initiative on DMD were concentrated on the three main areas; 1. In the context of the Covid-19, UNDP DMD focused on the coordination and collaboration with relevant UN and other partners to reinforce a collective voice in advocating for the concerns and needs of migrants and displaced persons during COVID-19 and beyond; 2. Developing and positioning DMD as an integrated policy and programming portfolio within UNDP, globally, regionally and (sub-)nationally in line with the Global Compact for Migration and Displacement process 3. Exploring and piloting innovative programming opportunities for the development of the full proposal for the initiative DMD in which the objective has been adjusted to ensure its relevance and response to the impact of the pandemic on the migrant and displaced people communities. Sub-activities included the mapping of informal urban settlements in Metro Manila/Philippines and Ho Chi Minh City/Viet Nam; the youth social entrepreneurial solutions for livelihood opportunities, resilience and social cohesion; and Blue/Green Economic Transformations (Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao) in the Philippines. The results from the pilot initiative DMD will inform the development of the full project proposal on DMD which will be submitted to the Embassy for consideration by November 2021.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
